fields.description:
In the demo

document.getElementById('myGrid').style.display = 'none'
let fiveFirst = gridOptions.columnApi.getAllDisplayedColumns().map ((it)=>it.colDef).slice (0,5)
gridOptions.api.setColumnDefs (fiveFirst)
document.getElementById('myGrid').style.display = 'block'
gridOptions.api.doLayout()
++

This should show the new columns, but it only shows one column

+++

If you resize the window it works

!!!!

GridCore.doLayout

if(windowResized)  -> this should be if windowResized || columnsChanged
fields.summary: Api.doLayout does not refresh columns after setColumnDef if following steps in Desc

fields.description:
Current behavior
The filter panel will still persist a value after removing in range filter.

Expected behavior
Upon removal of upper limit, if both limits are null, filter panel should be empty.

Minimal reproduction of the problem with instructions

open https://www.ag-grid.com/example.php
select Total Winnings number filter
select In range
enter lower limit, i.e. 45
enter upper limit i.e. 500,000
remove lower limit
remove upper limit
observe filter
fields.summary: 'In Range' filter issue

fields.description:
Copying a range-selected list of cells, where a cell contains an actual newline value \n and then pasting it somewhere else, either in Excel or Ag-Grid, will cause each newline value to start a new cell, instead of pasting in the original cell.

The reason for that is, while Ag-Grid actually "properly" parses the TSV format during pasting (that means, cells containing newlines will be quoted), it does not properly create a TSV format with quotes during the copy operation in ClipboardService.prototype.copySelectedRangeToClipboard

Other parts of Ag-Grid, e.g. ClipboardService.prototype.copySelectedRowsToClipboard properly implement this, as they re-use the CSV generation code.
fields.summary: Range Selection Copy does not quote cells containing newlines unlike Selected Rows Copy

fields.description:
Seems like a regression in 13.1.2

When clicking on a grid cell in Chrome, the focus style (with a default blue border) is applied to indicate that the cell has been clicked on when the suppressCellSelection flag in grid options is set to true. While this behavior is present in the current version (13.1.2) it appears that this first broke in 13.0.0.

Plunker of previous behavior:
https://plnkr.co/edit/yqQ68TqxF5KPjwH6PXS7

Plunker of current (broken) behavior:
https://plnkr.co/edit/aUj5d3nxdj1TjJHlhacZ
fields.summary: Grid Cell Receives Focus (and outline) when suppressCellSelection is set to true

issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: Work has been completed on this issue.
resolution.name: Done

fields.description:
the user on github says that the order of the rows in the dom is not consistent with the order of the rows in the grid, so when you tab into the grid, it's the first row in the dom that gets the focus, not the first row in the grid.

this is how the grid should work, the rows are not necessarily added in the order they appear.

options to fix:
1) when user tabs into the grid, somehow put the focus on the first row - which would be tricky if the user is scrolled down.
2) let the user decide somehow how to handle this. i think this is a can of worms, however if we can document somehow to the user can catch the tab event, and then let them decide which row / cell gets the focus, then this would all go away.


niall thought - have thought about this a lot, and think with row virtualisation (ie the first rendered row will not be row 1, and won't even be the first row on the screen with the rowBuffer), so i am deciding on option 1 above. i see some interesting ideas on the link here:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/10731468/override-default-tabbing-navigation
in particular, i think the onus should be on the user to put a listener on the last item they have, and then they do some gridApi calls to maybe 1) scroll grid to first row and then 2) put focus on first cell.
fields.summary: [tabbing] tabbing into the grid goes into the wrong cell
